participant_id.Description: Unique BIDS identifier for the participant in this study.

ASSQ_02.LongName: is regarded as an 'eccentric professor' by the other children

ASSQ_03.LongName: lives somewhat in a world of his/her own with restricted idiosyncratic intellectual interests

ASSQ_04.LongName: accumulates facts on certain subjects (good rote memory) but does not really understand the meaning

ASSQ_05.LongName: has a literal understanding of ambiguous and metaphoric language

ASSQ_06.LongName: has a deviant style of communication with a formal, fussy, 'old-fashioned' or 'robot-like' language

ASSQ_08.LongName: has a different voice or speech

ASSQ_9.LongName: expresses sounds involuntarily; clears throat, grunts, smacks, cries or screams

ASSQ_10.LongName: is surprisingly good at some things and surprisingly poor at others

ASSQ_11.LongName: uses language freely but fails to make adjustments to fit social contexts or the needs of different listeners

ASSQ_14.LongName: has a deviant style of gaze

ASSQ_15.LongName: wishes to be sociable but fails to make relationships with peers

ASSQ_16.LongName: can be with other children but only on his/her terms

ASSQ_19.LongName: is poor at games; no idea of cooperating in a team, scores 'own goals'

ASSQ_20.LongName: has clumsy, ill coordinated, ungainly, awkward movements or gestures

ASSQ_21.LongName: has involuntary face or body movements

ASSQ_22.LongName: has difficulties in completing simple daily activities because of compulsory repetition of certain actions or thoughts

ASSQ_23.LongName: has special routines; insists on no change

ASSQ_28.Description:
Total scores range from 0 to 54 with higher scores indicating greater exhibition of behavioral characteristics of Asperger syndrome. This questionnaire is not intended for diagnostic purposes, but as an initial screening measure. A score over 20 indicates that the participant should be referred for detailed assessment. | Calculation = iif  ([ASSQ_01]==0,0)+ iif  ([ASSQ_01]==2,1)+iif  ([ASSQ_01]==3,2)+
